more_info: A curated grouping of biomarkers that may work together to indicate a biological state.
Chemical Entities of Biological Interest (ChEBI) provides a database of small molecular entities.
ChEMBL is a manually curated database of bioactive molecules with drug-like properties.
A structured vocabulary for cell types across species, used to standardize cell information.
A defined group of cells curated together based on shared properties or experimental criteria.
A dataset providing detailed descriptions or measurements of various cell sets.
A standardized ontology for human diseases, providing consistent definitions and relationships.
A collection of organized data points relevant to the biological studies.
Identifiers from the Ensembl database, which provides genome-related information including gene annotations.
A comprehensive framework for representing gene and gene product attributes across species.
The official symbols assigned to genes by recognized nomenclature authorities.
Based on the Human Phenotype Ontology, this collection describes abnormal human phenotypic features.
Data reflecting the developmental stages of human samples.
Data reflecting the developmental stages of mouse samples.
MONDO merges multiple disease resources into a unified ontology for diseases.
MP
A classification system for organisms using taxonomic identifiers from the NCBI database.
Identifiers and information from ClinicalTrials.gov, representing clinical study data.
A curated resource on rare diseases, primarily provided by the Orphanet database.
An ontology describing the qualities of phenotypes observed in biological organisms.
Based on a provisional cell ontology, this collection classifies different cell types.
A cell set defined within the provisional cell ontology framework.
A structured vocabulary and identifiers for protein entities based on the Protein Ontology.
Scientific articles and publications relevant to the biological data.
Standardized biological sequences, such as those from the NCBI RefSeq database.
A controlled vocabulary for the parts and properties of biological sequences.
A cross-species ontology that provides a unified representation of anatomical structures.
